Expectation1: Ensure client satisfaction and address any concerns or complaints professionally
Situation1: An easygoing regular politely asks for a tiny adjustment to their fringe.
Expectation2: Provide clients with clear and accurate legal advice
Situation2: The client is facing an urgent legal issue and relies on precise advice for immediate action
Story: I was halfway through trimming Maria’s fringe, her laughter filling the salon as she recounted her weekend, when my phone buzzed insistently in my pocket. I glanced at the screen—my legal client, desperate for advice, the subject line screaming “URGENT.” Maria caught my distracted look and smiled, “Could you just take a little more off the side?” Her trust in me was clear; she expected me to focus, to make her feel cared for, to leave her looking her best. But my mind raced with the legal case: if I didn’t respond now, my client might make a costly mistake. I could hear the expectation in their last message—clarity, accuracy, immediate guidance. My scissors hovered, my heart pounding. I wanted to be present for Maria, to honor her loyalty, but the weight of my other client’s crisis pressed on me. I felt split in two, each role demanding my full attention, each client relying on me for something only I could give.
